comment.body: @Wumaogou All nations including Korea and Japan are shits. But people in it are some shits and some treasures.
@Wumaogou: Triggering useless hatred against a certain group of uncertain many people doesn't solve anything, but calls for bloody massacre as have happened so many times in human history.
Women from all over the world testified they were treated like sex slaves by Japanese army. Bad money must be backing up all these fake news, ha?

@Wumaogou: Japanese government is already bankrupted, but just breathing by sucking blood from its people. It had spent all the money which was given by its people, in supporting this kind of pervert or the rightist zombies. Now they have only one option to burn all those debts owed to its people. That option is to start a bloody war in Asia again. Like Hitler did. Like old jap imperialists did. This pervert is a kind of wooden chessmen which is used up by the mad rightists. He doesn't care about others' pain nor despair just like a reptile.
Do u prefer a kind of small button menu?

Technically no problem. Run ZeroNet --ui_ip [your laptop IP]. And open http://[your laptop IP]:43110 in your phone. But sometimes phone browser is lack of some features of javascript to display properly. Try other phone browsers and let me know the result.
@Binchan: Oh my goodness, why? even javascript encryption doesn't afford it?
@Binchan: I'm not a coder but I think everyone here has his own private-public key and which could encrypt the passphrase anyway, couldn't it?
Better have a bash script encrypted into 2D QR code?

@Binchan: The initial passphrase recognition is done by zeronet.py, isn't it? All we need are zeronet.py's private key, public key, zeronet.py's pgp-decryption module and pgp-encryption javascript code (or java assembly code, or virtual bash for pgp-encryption command) ? (Though I don't know if there's something like those in the world :p
@Binchan: Ah, additionally zeronet.py must need the client's public key as well to send zeronet.py's public key to the client privately..
@Binchan: $ zeronet.py --ui_password [my_public_key.asc]; No need of passphrase, isn't it?
